# <a id="src-main"></a> FY2025 Strategic Outlook and Financial Performance Targets

Based on the Q1 FY2025 earnings call transcript, management provided the following specific guidance and targets.

### **1\. Full Year FY2025 Targets**

Management reiterated some prior guidance while raising targets for Adjusted EBITDA and Free Cash Flow.

*   **Total Revenue:** "Our FY '25 outlook for total revenue remains unchanged at **$2.4 billion to $2.5 billion**"[[Source 1]](#src-1).
*   **Total Gross Margin:** The outlook "remains unchanged at **49%**"[[Source 1]](#src-1).
*   **Adjusted EBITDA:** Management raised the guidance range by 40million.LizCoddingtonstated : "WeareraisingourFY^{â€²}25adjustedEBITDAguidance...to âˆ— âˆ—240 million to $290 million\*\*"[[Source 1]](#src-1).
*   **Free Cash Flow:** "We are also raising our free cash flow target to **at least $125 million** an increase of $50 million from our previous guidance"[[Source 2]](#src-2).
*   **Paid Connected Fitness Subscriptions:** The guidance range of "**2.68 million to 2.75 million** remains unchanged"[[Source 3]](#src-3).
*   **Paid App Subscriptions:** Management lowered this guidance by 20,000 subscriptions to a range of "**550,000 to 600,000**"[[Source 4]](#src-4).
*   **Churn:** Management expects "average net monthly paid connected fitness churn will continue to **increase modestly year over year**"[[Source 3]](#src-3).

### **2\. Q2 FY2025 Expectations**

For the second quarter, management provided specific ranges reflecting seasonal trends and increased marketing spend.

*   **Total Revenue:** "**$640 million to $660 million**," which reflects a sequential increase due to holiday hardware sales[[Source 5]](#src-5).
*   **Paid Connected Fitness Subscriptions:** "**2.84 million to 2.86 million**," reflecting a "sequential decrease of 50,000 subscribers at the midpoint"[[Source 6]](#src-6).
*   **Paid App Subscriptions:** "**560,000 to 580,000**," reflecting a sequential decrease of 12,000 subscribers[[Source 5]](#src-5).
*   **Total Gross Margin:** "**46.5%**," which reflects an expected sequential decline "as a result of a seasonal mix shift toward our connected fitness Product segment"[[Source 5]](#src-5).
*   **Adjusted EBITDA:** "**$20 million to $30 million**," reflecting a sequential decline mainly due to "higher sales and marketing expenses as we increased media spend for the holiday season"[[Source 3]](#src-3).
*   **Churn:** Management expects the churn rate to "**slightly improve sequentially** in Q2"[[Source 6]](#src-6).

### **3\. Cost Restructuring Milestones**

Management confirmed they are on track to meet the savings goals announced in the May 2024 restructuring plan.

*   **Total Run-Rate Savings:** Interim Co-CEO Karen Boone reiterated the goal of "delivering **over $200 million of run rate cost savings** by the end of fiscal year '25"[[Source 7]](#src-7).
*   **Payroll-Related Savings (Completed):** CFO Liz Coddington confirmed that as of the end of Q1, they have "actioned all payroll-related changes that were assumed in the restructuring plan, which will deliver **over $100 million of annualized run rate savings**"[[Source 8]](#src-8).
*   **Additional Efficiencies:** Management noted they are realizing some savings "faster than we anticipated" and finding "additional cost efficiency through **reductions to media spend** that were not included in our $200 million restructuring goals"[[Source 8]](#src-8).

# <a id="src-2"></a>Source: q1 2025 earnings call transcript.md (Citation 2)



## [Main Content](#src-main) 

Our primary focus for FY '25 is delivering our key financial results, which include total revenue, total gross margin, and adjusted EBITDA. We are prioritizing these metrics, along with delivering free cash flow. Our FY '25 outlook for total revenue remains unchanged at $2.4 billion to $2.5 billion, as well as our outlook for total gross margin, which remains unchanged at 49%. We are raising our FY '25 adjusted EBITDA guidance by $40 million to $240 million to $290 million, which reflects our continued improvement in profitability, largely due to gross margin expansion the operating cost savings we expect to achieve related to our previously announced cost restructuring plan and reduced media spend year over year.

We are also raising our free cash flow target to at least $125 million an increase of $50 million from our previous guidance, primarily from lower inventory production that we expect to create a greater working capital tailwind, as well as continued operating expense efficiencies. Following our Q1 free cash flow result of $11 million, we do expect to achieve positive free cash flow in all four quarters of the fiscal year. We expect to make meaningful progress in deleveraging our balance sheet throughout FY '25 and beyond. And now I'd like to turn it back to Chris for some closing remarks.

# <a id="src-1"></a>Source: q1 2026 earnings call transcript.md (Citation 1)



## [Main Content](#src-main) 

We ended the quarter with 542,000 ending paid app subscriptions, inclusive of subscriptions from our acquisition of Breathwrk. Total revenue was $551 million in Q1, comprising $152 million of Connected Fitness products revenue and $398 million of subscription revenue, outperforming the high end of our guidance range by $6 million. Outperformance relative to guidance was primarily driven by Connected Fitness products revenue from higher-than-expected hardware sales of both Peloton and Precor products. Connected Fitness products revenue decreased $7 million or 5% year-over-year, driven by lower equipment sales and deliveries, partially offset by a mix toward higher-priced products.

# <a id="src-2"></a>Source: q1 2026 earnings call transcript.md (Citation 2)



## [Main Content](#src-main) 

Liz Coddington Chief Financial Officer

Thanks, Peter. I want to begin with our first quarter financial results in which we exceeded the high end of our guidance on most key metrics. We ended the first quarter with 2.732 million Paid Connected Fitness Subscriptions, reflecting a decrease of 6% year-over-year. Q1 is typically a seasonally lower quarter for hardware sales and seasonally higher quarter for churn. We exceeded the high end of our guidance range by 2,000, driven by higher-than-expected gross additions. Connected Fitness gross additions outperformed our expectations due to higher unit sales of our Connected Fitness products in both first-party and third-party retail channels. Average net monthly Paid Connected Fitness Subscription churn was 1.6%, an improvement of 20 basis points both year-over-year and 10 basis points quarter-over-quarter, in line with our expectations.

# <a id="src-3"></a>Source: q1 2026 earnings call transcript.md (Citation 3)



## [Main Content](#src-main) 

Adjusted EBITDA was $118 million in Q1, which was a $2 million or 2% improvement year-over-year and $18 million above the high end of our guidance range. To note, the $13.5 million accrual for Bike+ seat post inventory costs was not added back to adjusted EBITDA. We generated $67 million of free cash flow in Q1, an increase of $57 million year-over-year, significantly outperforming our prior expectation for slightly negative cash flow in the quarter. Free cash flow benefited from tariff-related favorability associated with both lower-than-expected tariff rates and delayed timing for certain tariffs going into effect, lower operating costs associated with realizing indirect cost savings faster than anticipated, revenue favorability and other smaller impacts.

# <a id="src-4"></a>Source: q1 2026 earnings call transcript.md (Citation 4)



## [Main Content](#src-main) 

Subscription revenue decreased $28 million or 7% year-over-year, primarily driven by lower ending Paid Connected Fitness Subscriptions, lower content licensing revenue and lower ending paid app subscriptions, partly offset by used equipment activation fee revenue, which was introduced in late August of fiscal 2025. Total gross profit was $284 million in Q1, a decrease of $20 million or 7% year-over-year. Total gross margin was 51.5%, a decrease of 30 basis points year-over-year and 50 basis points below our guidance of 52%. Total gross margin was negatively impacted by a $13.5 million accrual for Bike+ seat post inventory costs this quarter, in addition to $3 million we accrued in the prior quarter, representing a total estimated impact of $16.5 million. Excluding this $13.5 million charge in Q1, total gross margin would have been 54% or 200 basis points above our Q1 guidance.

# <a id="src-5"></a>Source: q1 2026 earnings call transcript.md (Citation 5)



## [Main Content](#src-main) 

Next, I'd like to share context for our financial outlook for Q2 and the remainder of the fiscal year. Our full year fiscal 2026 revenue outlook of $2.4 billion to $2.5 billion is unchanged from what we provided last quarter and reflects a 2% revenue decrease year-over-year at the midpoint. Our recently announced changes to subscription pricing were incorporated into our previous full year outlook. And so far, the impact of those changes has been in line with our expectations. We are pleased that our members continue to see the value in their Peloton membership and the recently added benefits like Peloton IQ, Club Peloton, Breathwrk and more.

# <a id="src-6"></a>Source: q1 2026 earnings call transcript.md (Citation 6)



## [Main Content](#src-main) 

As we noted last quarter, our full year guidance anticipates an inflection toward growth during certain quarters within the fiscal year. Our Q2 revenue outlook of $665 million to $685 million reflects this expectation with a slight increase of 0.2% year-over-year at the midpoint and an increase of 23% quarter-over-quarter as a result of seasonally higher equipment sales and recent pricing changes. We are raising our full year fiscal 2026 guidance for total gross margin to 52%, which is an increase of 100 basis points from our prior guidance and an improvement of 110 basis points year-over-year, primarily driven by favorable tariff rates relative to our prior full year guidance as policy continues to evolve, a favorable mix of sales toward higher-margin products and our continued focus on driving cost efficiency to our supply chain. These tailwinds are partially offset by the accrual for the Bike+ seat post inventory impact in Q1.

# <a id="src-7"></a>Source: q1 2026 earnings call transcript.md (Citation 7)



## [Main Content](#src-main) 

Q2 total gross margin is expected to be roughly 49%, down 250 basis points quarter-over-quarter due to an expected seasonally higher mix of Connected Fitness products revenue. We are raising our full year fiscal 2026 guidance for adjusted EBITDA to $425 million to $475 million, reflecting an increase of $25 million from our prior guidance and an improvement of 12% year-over-year at the midpoint, driven by favorable gross profit and operating expenses, reflecting our expectation for realizing cost savings faster than previously anticipated. To note, we are increasing our full year guidance by $25 million, notwithstanding the $13.5 million accrual for Bike+ seat post inventory costs in Q1.

# <a id="src-8"></a>Source: q1 2026 earnings call transcript.md (Citation 8)



## [Main Content](#src-main) 

Generating meaningful free cash flow remains a top priority. We are raising our full year fiscal 2026 minimum free cash flow target by $50 million to at least $250 million, reflecting the benefit of lower tariffs, both from lower rates and later-than-expected implementation timing and our progress on realizing indirect cost savings sooner. This target reflects our expectations for a roughly $45 million impact to free cash flow as a result of tariff exposure, which remains a dynamic situation that may change in the future. Overall, our guidance for Q2 and the remainder of the fiscal year reflects continued improvement in profitability and progress toward revenue growth. We still expect to achieve the important milestone of positive operating income on a full year basis in fiscal 2026.

# <a id="src-9"></a>Source: q1 2026 earnings call transcript.md (Citation 9)



## [Main Content](#src-main) 

Our Q2 outlook for adjusted EBITDA of $55 million to $75 million reflects an increase of 11% year-over-year at the midpoint, but a decrease of 45% quarter-over-quarter due to seasonally higher marketing spend in Q2. Our Q2 guidance for ending Paid Connected Fitness Subscriptions of 2.64 million to 2.67 million reflects a decrease of 8% year-over-year at the midpoint. Average net monthly Paid Connected Fitness Subscription churn is expected to increase year-over-year and quarter-over-quarter due to an increase in subscription cancellations and pauses following our pricing changes announced on October 1. However, our guidance reflects an expectation that our net churn rate will be flat year-over-year in full year fiscal 2026. We also expect gross additions to decrease year-over-year as a result of an expected year-over-year decrease in hardware sales.

### Additional Strategic Targets

*   **Gross Margin Long-Term:** Management has stated a goal for Connected Fitness Product Gross Margins to eventually be in the **~20% range**[[Source 17]](#src-17).
*   **LTV to CAC:** Management aims to reach a Lifetime Value to Customer Acquisition Cost ratio of **2x to 3x** (ideally closer to 3x)[[Source 18]](#src-18)[[Source 19]](#src-19).
*   **Deleveraging:** The company expects to make meaningful progress deleveraging the balance sheet through FY2025 and beyond, specifically mentioning the paydown of **~$200M** in convertible notes due in February 2026[[Source 7]](#src-7)[[Source 20]](#src-20).
*   **Restructuring:** The "2025 Restructuring Plan" (announced Aug 2025) is expected to be substantially implemented by the end of Fiscal 2026, targeting **$100M** in run-rate savings[[Source 21]](#src-21)[[Source 22]](#src-22).

# <a id="src-main"></a> Peloton: Strategic Pivot and the Path to Growth

Based on the J.P. Morgan analyst reports from August and November 2025, the firm maintains a **Neutral** rating on Peloton. The analysts acknowledge Peloton's status as a market leader with a loyal base but highlight significant challenges regarding the company's ability to return to sustainable top-line growth.

### **Competitive Positioning**

J.P. Morgan positions Peloton as the dominant player in interactive fitness, characterized by a unique vertically integrated business model.

*   **Market Leadership and Scale:** Peloton is identified as the "largest interactive fitness platform in the world" with over 6 million members globally[[Source 1]](#src-1)[[Source 2]](#src-2). The analysts note that Peloton's membership represents only ~4% of global gym memberships, suggesting a significant theoretical runway for future growth[[Source 1]](#src-1)[[Source 2]](#src-2).
*   **Vertically Integrated Model:** A key competitive advantage identified is Peloton's control over the "entire member journey" through its vertically integrated model (hardware, software, and content). This allows the company to deliver a "members-first mission" and drives a "passionate and highly engaged member base"[[Source 3]](#src-3)[[Source 4]](#src-4).
*   **Valuation Discount:** Despite its market leadership, Peloton trades at a discount compared to consumer subscription peers. As of November 2025, the price target of $9.00 is based on ~12x CY27 estimated Free Cash Flow (FCF), representing a discount to peers trading at an average of ~38x due to Peloton's "lower growth & profit profile"[[Source 5]](#src-5).

### **Key Opportunities**

The reports highlight several strategic initiatives implemented by CEO Peter Stern intended to drive profitability and eventually restore growth.

*   **Strategic Pivot to Wellness:** A major opportunity identified is broadening Pelotonâ€™s focus beyond cardio fitness to include "wellness." This includes scaling offerings in **Strength** and entering new categories such as **Meditation, Sleep, Recovery, Nutrition, and Hydration**[[Source 6]](#src-6)[[Source 7]](#src-7).
*   **Cost Rationalization and Efficiency:** J.P. Morgan views the company's cost discipline positively. Peloton is on track to realize over **$100 million in annualized savings** by the end of FY2026 through headcount reductions, lower indirect spend, and work relocation[[Source 8]](#src-8)[[Source 9]](#src-9). The analysts are encouraged by the company's progress in improving profit, ramping FCF, and deleveraging the balance sheet[[Source 6]](#src-6)[[Source 10]](#src-10).
*   **Product Innovation:** The analysts point to investments in driving awareness for new products, specifically the **Peloton Cross Training Series** and **Peloton IQ** (AI-driven personalization), as key drivers for future growth[[Source 8]](#src-8)[[Source 11]](#src-11).
*   **Pricing and Monetization:** There is an opportunity to improve unit economics through pricing adjustments. This includes rationalizing promotions, introducing optional expert assembly fees, and potential upside from All-Access subscription price increases[[Source 7]](#src-7)\> <[[Source 12]](#src-12)[[Source 13]](#src-13).
*   **Commercial and Retail Expansion:** The creation of a **unified commercial business unit** combining Peloton and Precor is seen as a strategic lever to expand reach[[Source 14]](#src-14). Additionally, the analysts note the plan to expand from one to ten "microstores" to grow physical presence efficiently[[Source 15]](#src-15).

### **Key Threats and Risks**

Despite the operational improvements, J.P. Morgan identifies substantial risks, primarily centered on the uncertainty of demand and intense market competition.

*   **Visibility on Growth:** The most significant threat identified is the difficulty in returning to Connected Fitness (CF) subscriber and revenue growth. The analysts note that "visibility is limited given secular & macro pressures" and that a return to growth remains "challenging"[[Source 3]](#src-3)[[Source 4]](#src-4).
*   **Intense Competition:** The reports identify heavy competition as a downside risk, specifically citing **Apple Fitness+, Equinox/SoulCycle, BODY, Tonal, and Tempo** as key rivals[[Source 16]](#src-16)[[Source 17]](#src-17).
*   **Macroeconomic and Tariff Headwinds:** The company faces "secular & macro pressures"[[Source 3]](#src-3). Specific headwinds include tariffs, with Peloton anticipating additional reciprocal tariffs on imported tablets from Thailand and existing tariffs on aluminum content[[Source 8]](#src-8)[[Source 15]](#src-15).
*   **Valuation Support:** There is a risk regarding "less traditional valuation support" compared to subscription peers, as there is no clear comparable company and limited visibility into near-term demand trends[[Source 18]](#src-18)[[Source 19]](#src-19).

### **Current Employee Count**

**Key Observation:** The decline in core Peloton staff is significant. While the FY2023 count (3,584) excluded Precor, the FY2025 count (2,656) _includes_ Precor, indicating that the reduction in legacy Peloton staff is steeper than the headline numbers suggest.

### **Specific Restructuring Actions**

The Proxy Statements and ESG reports highlight three major restructuring phases aimed at reducing fixed costs and improving cash flow.

*   **2022 Restructuring Plan:** Initiated to realign operational focus, this plan involved "getting the right people in the right roles" and stabilizing cash flow[[Source 5]](#src-5). The ESG report noted that the company provided support to team members impacted by this restructuring, including cash compensation, extended healthcare, and career support services[[Source 6]](#src-6).
*   **2024 Restructuring Plan:** Announced in May 2024, this plan aimed to position the company for sustained positive free cash flow. It included a **global headcount reduction of approximately 15%**, which impacted roughly **400 team members**[[Source 7]](#src-7)[[Source 8]](#src-8).
*   **2025 Restructuring Plan:** In August 2025, the company announced a new plan involving further "reduction in global headcount" to achieve at least **$100 million in run-rate cost savings** by the end of Fiscal 2026[[Source 9]](#src-9)[[Source 10]](#src-10).

### **Workforce Strategy & Support**

Despite the reductions, the ESG and Proxy reports emphasize a strategy of "talent density" and support for the remaining workforce:

*   **Compensation:** The company completed pay equity studies in FY2023 and FY2025, finding no statistically significant pay gaps based on gender or race[[Source 11]](#src-11)[[Source 12]](#src-12).
*   **Wages:** Peloton offers a starting hourly rate of no less than $19 for non-sales hourly roles in the US[[Source 12]](#src-12).
*   **Engagement:** In FY2025, the company reported an engagement score of 77% favorable and an Employee Net Promoter Score (eNPS) of 74%, an increase of 12 points from the prior year[[Source 13]](#src-13).

# <a id="src-main"></a> Peloton's Path to Financial Decline: Five Strategic Failures

Based on the Managementâ€™s Discussion and Analysis (MD&A) and Risk Factors sections of the Annual Reports (Form 10-K) for Fiscal Years 2022 through 2024, Peloton management identified the following five primary factors as the causes of the company's financial difficulties.

### 1\. Inability to Accurately Forecast Post-Pandemic Demand

Management consistently identified the extreme difficulty in forecasting consumer behavior following the COVID-19 pandemic as a root cause of financial strain. The company scaled its operations assuming pandemic-era growth would persist, leading to significant misalignment when demand normalized.

*   **Management Quote:** "Fluctuations in demand and supply that we have been navigating during this time period led us to grow our operations beyond what we believe is currently best suited to our business."[[Source 1]](#src-1)
*   **Management Quote:** "We have had significant difficulty in forecasting near-term consumer demand and, as a result, our expected near-term operating performance."[[Source 1]](#src-1),[[Source 2]](#src-2)

### 2\. Excess Inventory and Supply Chain Commitments

Directly resulting from the forecasting challenges mentioned above, Peloton faced severe inventory gluts. The company had committed to long-term supply agreements and built up stock to meet anticipated demand that did not materialize, forcing them to write down inventory value and incur storage costs.

*   **Management Quote:** "Inventory levels in excess of consumer demand has resulted in, and may continue to result in inventory write-downs or write-offs and the sale of excess inventory at discounted prices."[[Source 3]](#src-3)
*   **Management Quote:** "Connected Fitness Products cost of revenue... increased... primarily driven by increased inventory reserves... related to excess inventory we do not expect to sell above cost and write-downs of raw materials that we estimate would have no future use."[[Source 4]](#src-4)

### 3\. Product Safety Issues and Recalls (Tread+ and Bike Seat Post)

Operational and financial momentum was severely impacted by safety recalls, specifically regarding the Tread+ (May 2021) and the original Bike seat post (May 2023). These recalls resulted in halted sales, expensive retrofits, returns, legal costs, and reputational damage.

*   **Management Quote:** "The recall, the possibility that the CPSC or other regulators could assess penalties or fines against us, and the risk that the CPSC or we could determine to recall any other product now or in the future, may adversely impact our operating results, brand reputation, and business."[[Source 5]](#src-5)
*   **Management Quote:** "We are presently subject to class action litigation, private personal injury claims and other regulatory proceedings... related to the Tread+ and Bike recalls and other matters that... could harm our reputation, divert managementâ€™s attention... and result in substantial legal fees, judgments, fines, penalties, and other costs."[[Source 6]](#src-6)

### 4\. Macroeconomic Headwinds and Inflation

Management identified external economic pressures as a significant factor reducing consumer discretionary spending. Rising inflation increased the company's component and logistics costs while simultaneously reducing the purchasing power of their target consumers.

*   **Management Quote:** "Unfavorable economic conditions may lead consumers to delay or reduce purchases of our products and services and consumer demand for our products and services may not grow as we expect."[[Source 7]](#src-7)
*   **Management Quote:** "Our business may continue to be impacted by inflation in the future which could have an adverse effect on our ability to maintain current levels of gross margin and operating expenses... if we are unable to fully offset such higher costs through price increases."[[Source 8]](#src-8)

### 5\. Market Saturation and Intense Competition

As the connected fitness market matured, Peloton faced challenges regarding market saturation and intense competition from both digital apps and traditional gyms reopening. Management noted that the rapid growth phase of the industry had slowed, making customer acquisition more difficult and costly.

*   **Management Quote:** "The connected fitness and wellness market at large is heavily saturated, and the demand for and market acceptance of new products and services in the market is uncertain."[[Source 9]](#src-9)
*   **Management Quote:** "We face significant competition in every aspect of our business, including from at-home fitness equipment and content, fitness clubs, in-studio fitness classes, and health and wellness apps."[[Source 10]](#src-10)

# <a id="src-main"></a> Peloton's Strategic Turnaround: From Expansion to Profitable Growth

Based on the FY2024 and FY2025 10-K filings and earnings call transcripts, Pelotonâ€™s turnaround strategy has shifted from rapid expansion to a focus on **sustainable, profitable growth** and **free cash flow**. Management executed this through three distinct restructuring plans (2022, 2024, and 2025) and specific operational initiatives designed to repair unit economics.

The following sections outline the key elements of these strategies.

### 1\. The Restructuring Plans (2022â€“2025)

Management implemented three major phases of restructuring to align the company's cost structure with its current revenue base.

**2022 Restructuring Plan**

**Feb 2022**<br>Focus: Exit owned manufacturing and logistics.

*   â€¢ **Manufacturing:** Exited all owned-manufacturing operations; expanded relationship with third-party manufacturer Rexon Industrial Corp[[Source 1]](#src-1).<br>â€¢ **Real Estate:** Closed assembly plants and sold the "Peloton Output Park" facility (shell)[[Source 1]](#src-1)[[Source 2]](#src-2).<br>â€¢ **Logistics:** Transitioned North American Field Operations to third-party logistics (3PL) providers[[Source 1]](#src-1).<br>â€¢ **Headcount:** Significant reduction in delivery workforce and member support roles[[Source 1]](#src-1).

Substantially completed by FY2025[[Source 3]](#src-3).

**2024 Restructuring Plan**

**April/May 2024**<br>Focus: Headcount and Retail Footprint.

*   â€¢ **Headcount:** Reduced global headcount by approximately 15% (impacting ~400 employees)[[Source 4]](#src-4)[[Source 5]](#src-5).<br>â€¢ **Retail:** Accelerated closures of retail showroom locations to reduce fixed costs[[Source 4]](#src-4)[[Source 6]](#src-6).

Targeted **$200 million** in annualized run-rate savings by the end of FY2025[[Source 7]](#src-7). Management reported exceeding this target[[Source 8]](#src-8).

**2025 Restructuring Plan**

**August 2025**<br>Focus: Operating Efficiency & Growth Reinvestment.

*   â€¢ **Headcount:** Further reduction in global headcount[[Source 9]](#src-9).<br>â€¢ **Cost Structure:** Continued improvement of operating efficiency to reinvest savings into differentiating capabilities[[Source 9]](#src-9).

Targeted at least **$100 million** in run-rate savings by the end of FY2026[[Source 10]](#src-10).

### 2\. Operational Turnaround Strategy

Beyond structural cost cutting, management implemented specific strategic initiatives to improve **unit economics** and **Gross Margin**.

Management moved away from "growth at all costs" to prioritizing the Lifetime Value (LTV) to Customer Acquisition Cost (CAC) ratio.

*   **Pricing & Promotions:** The company reduced promotional activity, aligning discounts strictly with product margin profiles[[Source 8]](#src-8)[[Source 11]](#src-11). In Q1 FY2025, Peloton raised prices on bike products in international markets to expand gross margins[[Source 12]](#src-12).
*   **Secondary Market Monetization:** A "Used Equipment Activation Fee" was launched to monetize second-hand hardware owners, increasing the LTV of customers joining via the secondary market[[Source 12]](#src-12)[[Source 13]](#src-13).
*   **Gross Margin Recovery:** By Q2 FY2025, Connected Fitness Product gross margin returned to double digits (12.9%) for the first time in over three years due to a favorable mix of premium products and pricing discipline[[Source 8]](#src-8)[[Source 14]](#src-14).

Peloton shifted its distribution strategy to lower fixed costs and meet customers where they shop.

*   **Retail Evolution:** The company continued closing underperforming first-party retail stores while testing cost-efficient "micro-store" concepts (e.g., Nashville)[[Source 15]](#src-15)[[Source 16]](#src-16).
*   **Third-Party Retail:** Aggressive expansion into third-party channels, including a seasonal partnership with **Costco** (selling Bike+) and distribution via **Amazon** and **FitShop** in Germany[[Source 15]](#src-15)[[Source 16]](#src-16).
*   **Commercial Business:** Peloton created a unified commercial business unit combining Peloton and **Precor** to target hospitality and gym markets, including a partnership with **Hyatt Hotels**[[Source 17]](#src-17)[[Source 18]](#src-18).

To drive retention and engagement (LTV), management invested in software and hardware innovations.

*   **Hardware Refresh:** Launched the **Cross Training Series** and **Peloton Pro Series** (commercial grade) in October 2025[[Source 19]](#src-19).
*   **New Software/Apps:**
    *   **Strength+ App:** A gym-focused app launched in December 2024 to target strength training users[[Source 20]](#src-20)[[Source 21]](#src-21).
    *   **Personalized Plans:** AI/ML-driven workout plans tailored to user goals[[Source 22]](#src-22).
    *   **Teams:** A social feature allowing members to share workouts and compete, launched in September 2024[[Source 23]](#src-23).
*   **Acquisitions:** Acquired **Breathwrk** in September 2025 to expand into mental wellness and breathing exercises[[Source 24]](#src-24).

A critical component of the turnaround was stabilizing the balance sheet.

*   **Refinancing:** In May 2024, Peloton completed a holistic refinancing to deleverage and extend debt maturities[[Source 25]](#src-25).
*   **Debt Reduction:** By Q2 FY2025, net debt had decreased by over **$280 million** (30%) year-over-year[[Source 26]](#src-26).
*   **Free Cash Flow:** The company shifted focus to generating meaningful Free Cash Flow, achieving **$323.7 million** in FY2025 compared to negative flows in prior years[[Source 27]](#src-27).

# <a id="src-main"></a> The Peter Stern Era: Pelotonâ€™s Strategic Evolution 2025

Based on the earnings transcripts, 8-K filings, and proxy statements from January 2025 through November 2025, Peter Sternâ€™s strategic vision centers on evolving Peloton from a connected fitness company into a broader "fitness and wellness" ecosystem. His stated purpose for the company is to "**empower people to live fit, strong, long, and happy**"[[Source 1]](#src-1)[[Source 2]](#src-2).

To achieve this, Stern defined a "magic formula" comprising premium equipment, AI-powered software, world-class instructors, and a supportive community[[Source 3]](#src-3)[[Source 4]](#src-4). Since taking over as CEO on January 1, 2025, he has implemented changes across four primary strategic pillars:

### 1\. Improve Member Outcomes through Innovation

Sternâ€™s strategy prioritizes holistic health outcomes over simple hardware sales, expanding into strength, mental wellness, and recovery.

*   **AI and Personalization (Peloton IQ):** Stern launched **Peloton IQ** in October 2025, an AI-powered personalized coach that uses data from wearables and class history to provide individual guidance and recommendations[[Source 5]](#src-5)[[Source 6]](#src-6).
*   **Hardware Overhaul (Cross Training Series):** In October 2025, Peloton released the **Cross Training Series** (Bike, Bike+, Tread, Tread+, Row+). These devices feature swivel screens for floor workouts and, in the "Plus" line, advanced computer vision to count reps and correct form[[Source 3]](#src-3)\> <[[Source 7]](#src-7)[[Source 8]](#src-8).
*   **Expansion into Wellness:**
    *   **Mental Fitness:** In September 2025, Peloton acquired **Breathwrk**, a subscription app for breathing exercises, integrating it into Peloton memberships[[Source 9]](#src-9)[[Source 10]](#src-10).
    *   **Medical Partnerships:** Stern announced collaborations with the **Hospital for Special Surgery** for injury prevention content and **Respin Health** to study and support menopause[[Source 11]](#src-11).
*   **Software Apps:** Stern oversaw the scaling of the **Strength+ App** (launched December 2024), designed for gym-based strength training[[Source 12]](#src-12)[[Source 13]](#src-13). Conversely, the company **discontinued the sale of the Peloton Guide** hardware in July 2025, shifting focus to software-based tracking[[Source 8]](#src-8).

### 2\. Meet Members Everywhere (Expansion of Distribution)

Stern shifted the companyâ€™s distribution strategy to meet customers in physical retail spaces and commercial settings.

*   **Commercial Push (Pro Series):** He established a unified commercial business unit combining Peloton and Precor. This included launching the **Peloton Pro Series** (commercial-grade Bike+, Tread+, and Row+) for hotels and multi-family residences[[Source 8]](#src-8)[[Source 14]](#src-14).
*   **Retail Partnerships & Footprint:**
    *   **Micro-Stores:** Expanded from one to ten "micro-stores" in the U.S. by late 2025 to provide capital-efficient physical touchpoints[[Source 15]](#src-15).
    *   **Third-Party Retail:** Entered a partnership with **Johnson Fitness & Wellness** to place products in 100 retail locations and utilized **Costco** as a seasonal partner[[Source 15]](#src-15)[[Source 16]](#src-16).
    *   **Precor Integration:** Leveraged Precorâ€™s infrastructure to handle installation and service for commercial clients[[Source 17]](#src-17).

### 3\. Make Members for Life (Deepening Connection)

To increase retention and lifetime value (LTV), Stern introduced gamification and loyalty mechanics.

*   **Club Peloton:** Launched a loyalty and recognition program in late 2025, where members unlock exclusive content and rewards based on engagement[[Source 18]](#src-18).
*   **Teams:** Introduced official instructor-led "Teams" (e.g., "Move for Life," "HYROX") to foster social connections and competition among members[[Source 16]](#src-16)[[Source 18]](#src-18).

### 4\. Operational Discipline and Financial Efficiency

Stern continued the restructuring efforts begun by his predecessors to ensure sustainable cash flow.

*   **2025 Restructuring Plan:** In August 2025, Stern announced a new restructuring plan involving global headcount reductions to target at least **$100 million in run-rate savings** by the end of FY2026[[Source 19]](#src-19)[[Source 20]](#src-20).
*   **Pricing Adjustments:** He implemented monetization initiatives, including expert assembly fees and subscription price changes in late 2025, accepting a temporary increase in churn to improve long-term unit economics[[Source 21]](#src-21)[[Source 22]](#src-22).
*   **Executive Compensation Redesign:** For FY2026, the compensation structure for leadership was redesigned to heavily weight performance-based stock units (PSUs) and reduce cash salaries, aligning executive pay more aggressively with shareholder value and free cash flow targets[[Source 23]](#src-23)[[Source 24]](#src-24).

# Peloton Interactive Inc. â€” Board of Directors Presentation
## Executive Business Intelligence Brief | Q1 FY2026

---

# SLIDE 1: From Crisis to Cash Flow â€” The Turnaround Story

## **Key Message**
Peloton has successfully completed a strategic pivot from a hardware-centric, vertically integrated business model to an asset-light, subscription-focused operation â€” transforming from burning $2.4B in cash (FY22) to generating $324M in free cash flow (FY25). The structural flaw has been addressed; the question is now whether this smaller, leaner company can return to growth.

---

### Supporting Points

**1. The Scale of the Collapse**
| Metric | FY21 Peak | FY25 | Change |
|--------|-----------|------|--------|
| Total Revenue | $4.02B | $2.49B | **-38%** |
| Hardware Revenue | $3.15B | $817M | **-74%** |
| Subscription Revenue | $872M | $1.67B | **+92%** |
| Adjusted EBITDA | +$254M | +$404M | +59%* |
| Free Cash Flow | -$492M | +$324M | **+$816M swing** |

*Note: FY22 EBITDA was -$983M, making the true recovery a $1.4B improvement

**2. The Root Cause Was Structural, Not Just Cyclical**
Management identified five causal factors, but the underlying structural flaw was Peloton's vertically integrated operating model (owned manufacturing, owned logistics, owned retail) which created massive fixed costs that couldn't flex when post-pandemic demand collapsed.

| What Broke | Impact | Restructuring Response |
|------------|--------|------------------------|
| Owned manufacturing | Overcapacity, inventory write-downs | Exited ALL owned manufacturing; partnered with Rexon |
| Owned logistics | High fixed costs, regional complexity | Shifted to 3PL nationwide |
| 135 retail showrooms | Unsustainable lease obligations | Closed most; pivoted to 10 micro-stores + third-party retail |
| Overstaffed organization | $983M negative EBITDA (FY22) | Reduced headcount from peak to 2,656 (-26% since FY23) |

**3. Revenue Mix Transformation**
The business model has fundamentally shifted:
- FY21: Hardware = 78% of revenue, Subscriptions = 22%
- FY25: Hardware = 33% of revenue, Subscriptions = **67%**

This is not shrinkageâ€”it's transformation. Subscription gross margins (~69%) are 5x hardware margins (~13.6%), meaning profitability improved even as revenue declined.

**4. Cash Position Stabilized**
- FY22: Consumed $2.36B in cash (negative FCF + restructuring charges)
- FY25: Generated $324M in free cash flow
- $722M unrestricted cash on hand
- On track to pay down ~$200M convertible notes (Feb 2026)

---

### Visualization Recommendation
**Two-panel chart:**
- **Left panel**: Stacked bar chart showing revenue composition shift (FY21 â†’ FY25) with hardware declining and subscriptions growing as proportion
- **Right panel**: Waterfall chart showing the free cash flow bridge from -$2.36B (FY22) to +$324M (FY25), with restructuring savings and margin improvement as the key drivers

---

### Actionable Insight

> **The restructuring addressed the root cause (fixed-cost vertical integration) rather than just treating symptoms.** However, this was a *survival* strategy, not a *growth* strategy. The company is now right-sized for a ~2.8M subscriber base generating ~$2.5B in revenue. 
>
> **Board Action Required**: Define the strategic intent â€” is Peloton a "harvest" business (maximize cash flow from existing base) or a "growth" business (reinvest to expand)? Current trajectory supports the former; Peter Stern's initiatives signal ambition for the latter. These require different capital allocation frameworks and management incentives.

---

### Speaker Notes

Peloton's crisis was fundamentally different from a typical demand shock. When pandemic tailwinds reversed in late 2021, the company discovered that its vertically integrated model â€” which had been a competitive advantage during hyper-growth â€” had become an existential threat. Unlike competitors who outsourced manufacturing and logistics, Peloton owned factories, warehouses, delivery fleets, and 135 retail showrooms. When revenue fell 38% from peak, these fixed costs couldn't flex, resulting in nearly $3 billion in losses over FY22-FY23.

The restructuring response was appropriately aggressive. By exiting all owned manufacturing (partnering with Rexon), shifting to third-party logistics, and closing most retail showrooms, management converted the cost structure from predominantly fixed to predominantly variable. This structural change is permanent and positions the company to remain profitable even if the subscriber base continues to erode modestly.

However, the board should recognize that this turnaround was achieved through contraction, not innovation. The company is significantly smaller than at its peak, and the current profitability depends on maintaining the existing subscriber base rather than growing it. The question facing the board is whether this is the steady state, or whether the new management team can reignite growth from this stabilized foundation.

### Speaker Notes

The execution scorecard tells a clear story: management can cut costs and improve margins, but hasn't yet proven they can grow the business. Over five consecutive quarters, the team has beaten guidance on profitability metrics, often by substantial margins. # SLIDE 3: Strategic Outlook â€” What Should the Board Do Next?

## **Key Message**
Peter Stern's strategy represents a coherent bet on extending member lifetime value and diversifying revenue streams beyond hardware sales. Early execution signals are positive, but the strategy carries material risks. The board should monitor three specific metrics as "trip wires" that would trigger strategy reassessment.

---

### Peter Stern's Strategic Framework (Since Jan 2025)

**Company Purpose**: "Empower people to live fit, strong, long, and happy"

**The "Magic Formula"**: Premium equipment + AI software + world-class instructors + supportive community

| **2. Meet Members Everywhere** | Peloton Pro Series (commercial), micro-stores (1â†’10), Johnson Fitness (100 locations), Precor integration | In progress | Precor in 60+ countries vs. Peloton in 6 |
| **3. Make Members for Life** | Club Peloton (loyalty), Teams (instructor-led communities) | Launched Oct 2025 | 500K+ engaged in Club Peloton |

---

### Actionable Insight: Three Board-Level Recommendations

#### **Recommendation 1: Monitor Content Licensing Revenue as Leading Indicator**
Content licensing (Lululemon, Hyatt, etc.) represents Peloton's ability to monetize its content platform beyond hardware sales â€” the core premise of the strategic pivot. This metric is not currently broken out separately in financials.

> **Board Action**: Request quarterly reporting on content licensing revenue as a percentage of total subscription revenue. Establish a target (e.g., 10% by FY27) and flag any quarters where it declines.

---

#### **Recommendation 2: Establish Subscriber Floor Threshold**
The current profitability model depends on maintaining a subscriber base large enough to cover fixed costs. Management has not disclosed the minimum viable subscriber count.

> **Board Action**: Work with management to define a "subscriber floor" â€” the threshold below which the cost structure would need further adjustment. Estimate: ~2.3-2.5M subscribers. If projected trajectory approaches this floor, trigger formal strategic review.

---

#### **Recommendation 3: Demand Concrete Growth Metrics by Q2 FY26**
Peter Stern has articulated a compelling vision but has not provided quantified growth targets. The board should not accept another quarter of "inflection toward growth" language without supporting metrics.

> **Board Action**: In the February 2026 earnings review, require management to present:
> - Target gross additions by channel (direct, third-party retail, commercial)
> - Expected customer acquisition cost (CAC) by channel
> - LTV/CAC ratio targets by customer segment
> - Timeline for revenue growth inflection (specific quarter, not "sometime in FY26")

---

### What Success Looks Like (12-Month Scorecard)

| Metric | RED Trigger | AMBER Watch | GREEN Target |
|--------|-------------|-------------|--------------|
| Ending Subscribers (Jun 2026) | <2.5M | 2.5-2.7M | >2.7M |
| Content Licensing as % Sub Revenue | <3% | 3-5% | >5% |
| Gross Additions (FY26) | Down >15% YoY | Down 5-15% | Flat or positive |
| Free Cash Flow | <$200M | $200-250M | >$250M |
| Churn (Full Year) | >1.8% | 1.6-1.8% | â‰¤1.6% |

---

### Speaker Notes

The strategic question facing Peloton is whether it can transition from a "stabilized decline" trajectory to a "sustainable growth" trajectory. Peter Stern's strategy represents a coherent approach to this challenge: extend the lifetime value of existing members through AI personalization and loyalty programs, while diversifying distribution through commercial/B2B channels and content licensing partnerships.

The early indicators are genuinely positive. Engagement is up 50% since October, Club Peloton has attracted over 500,000 participants, and member satisfaction scores have improved dramatically. The new Cross Training Series hardware has received positive reviews. These are the foundations for retention improvement.

However, the board should maintain appropriate skepticism about growth claims. Every initiative Peter Stern has announced is oriented toward making existing members more engaged and valuable â€” which is necessary but not sufficient for revenue growth. The company has not yet articulated a convincing plan to reverse the decline in new customer acquisition.

The three recommendations I've outlined are designed to give the board early warning signals if the strategy isn't working. Content licensing revenue is the clearest indicator of platform value beyond hardware. The subscriber floor establishes a boundary condition that would require strategic intervention. And demanding concrete growth metrics ensures management accountability.

If the February 2026 earnings call does not include quantified targets for acquisition and growth â€” with specific timelines and supporting unit economics â€” the board should consider whether the current strategy is capable of producing growth, or whether Peloton should be managed as a cash-generating business with a declining revenue trajectory.

Content from @peloton-presentation/peloton_dashboard_prompt.md:
# Project: Peloton Business Intelligence Dashboard

## Objective

Create a single-page interactive HTML dashboard that serves as a companion to my executive presentation on Peloton's turnaround. The dashboard should allow viewers to explore the underlying data and source materials that support the presentation's conclusions.

## Technical Requirements

- Single HTML file (can include inline CSS and JavaScript)
- Use Chart.js for visualizations
- Mobile-responsive design
- Host-ready for GitHub Pages
- Clean, professional aesthetic (dark mode preferred, similar to financial terminals)
- No external dependencies that require build steps

## Dashboard Structure

### Section 1: Financial Turnaround (Supports Slide 1)

**Chart 1: Revenue Trajectory**

- Type: Combo chart (bars for total revenue, line for subscription % of revenue)
- Data: FY2017-FY2025 annual revenue
- Annotations: Mark key events (COVID peak, restructuring announcements, CEO changes)
- Story panel below: [INSERT KEY INSIGHT FROM SLIDE 1 ABOUT REVENUE]

**Chart 2: Profitability Journey**

- Type: Line chart with area fill
- Data: Adjusted EBITDA and Free Cash Flow, FY2021-FY2025
- Highlight: The inflection point to profitability
- Story panel below: [INSERT KEY INSIGHT FROM SLIDE 1 ABOUT PROFITABILITY]

**Chart 3: Operational Restructuring**

- Type: Horizontal bar chart or waterfall
- Data: Headcount changes, retail location closures
- Story panel below: [INSERT KEY INSIGHT FROM SLIDE 1 ABOUT RESTRUCTURING SCALE]

### Section 2: Execution Scorecard (Supports Slide 2)

**Table 1: Targets vs Actuals**

- Interactive table with RAG status indicators
- Columns: Metric | Target | Actual | Status | Trend
- Rows: Cost savings, FCF, EBITDA, Subscribers, Churn, Margins
- Sortable and filterable
- Story panel below: [INSERT KEY INSIGHT FROM SLIDE 2 ABOUT MANAGEMENT CREDIBILITY]

**Chart 4: Subscriber Metrics**

- Type: Dual-axis chart
- Data: Connected Fitness Subs (bars), Churn Rate (line), FY2021-FY2025
- Story panel below: [INSERT KEY INSIGHT FROM SLIDE 2 ABOUT SUBSCRIBER HEALTH]

**Chart 5: Engagement Trends**

- Type: Line chart
- Data: Average monthly workouts per subscriber (if available across years)
- Story panel below: [INSERT KEY INSIGHT FROM SLIDE 2 ABOUT ENGAGEMENT]

### Section 3: Strategic Outlook (Supports Slide 3)

**Table 2: Opportunity Assessment**

- Columns: Opportunity | Probability | Impact | Recommendation
- Visual indicators for probability/impact (dots or bars)
- Story panel below: [INSERT KEY INSIGHT FROM SLIDE 3 ABOUT GROWTH OPTIONS]

**Table 3: Risk Assessment**

- Columns: Risk | Probability | Impact | Mitigation
- RAG status indicators
- Story panel below: [INSERT KEY INSIGHT FROM SLIDE 3 ABOUT RISKS]

**Chart 6: Market Context** (if market data available)

- Type: Area chart or bar chart
- Data: Connected fitness market size projections
- Peloton's position annotated
- Story panel below: [INSERT KEY INSIGHT FROM SLIDE 3 ABOUT MARKET]

### Section 4: Source Material Viewer

**Implementation Options (choose one):**

Option A: Hover Modal

- Each data point or insight has a small "source" icon
- Hovering reveals a modal with the original quote and document reference
- Modal includes: Quote text, Document name, Page/section reference

Option B: Expandable Sections

- Each story panel has a "View Sources" toggle
- Clicking expands to show all source citations for that section
- Collapsible accordion style

Option C: Side Panel

- Clicking any chart/table element opens a right-side panel
- Panel shows relevant source quotes
- Panel can be pinned open or auto-closes

**Source Data Structure:**
Each insight should link to source citations in this format:

```json
{
  "insight_id": "revenue_decline",
  "quote": "Total revenue decreased from $2.7B in FY24 to $2.49B in FY25...",
  "source": "10-K FY2025",
  "section": "MD&A - Results of Operations",
  "page": "45"
}
```

### Diagnosis

The diagnostic output confirms exactly why the commands failed:

1.  **Missing from Registry:** The path `C:\Program Files\Git\cmd` is **completely missing** from your computer's permanent configuration (both "System" and "User" levels).
2.  **Only GitHub CLI Exists:** While `GitHub CLI` is present in your PATH, standard `Git` is not.

**Why did it work before?**
Since the path is missing from the registry, it's likely that:
*   **Git was re-installed or updated:** Sometimes installers overwrite the `PATH` variable rather than appending to it, accidentally removing previous entries.
*   **Or, a temporary setup was used:** In the previous session, an environment script (like `vcvars64.bat` or a specific terminal profile) might have temporarily injected Git into the session, but that configuration doesn't persist to a generic command shell.

**Recommendation:**
To fix this permanently for all applications (including me and your own terminals):
1.  Open **"Edit the system environment variables"** in Windows Search.
2.  Click **Environment Variables**.
3.  Under **System variables**, find `Path`, click **Edit**, and add:
    `C:\Program Files\Git\cmd`

## MODEL âœ¨

### Answer

**Can you `npm install git`?**
**No.** `npm` is for JavaScript libraries. While there are some packages named "git", they are usually just wrappers or pure-JS implementations (like `isomorphic-git`) used *inside* a Node.js project. They do not install the system-wide `git.exe` tool that your terminal or VS Code needs.

### Why this is happening now
Since you mentioned installing the **Git GUI**, it is highly likely that during installation, the option **"Use Git from Git Bash only"** was selected (often the default) instead of **"Git from the command line"**. This keeps your PATH clean but makes `git` invisible to PowerShell and other tools.

### Best Alternative Solutions

Here are the best ways to fix this without manually editing environment variables:

**1. Re-run the Git Installer (Easiest & Safest)**
Download the installer from [git-scm.com](https://git-scm.com/download/win). When you run it, simply click "Next" until you see the screen **"Adjusting your PATH environment"**.
*   **Select:** "Git from the command line and also from 3rd-party software".
*   This will fix it permanently for all tools.

**2. Use "Git Bash" Terminal**
If you have Git GUI installed, you almost certainly have **Git Bash** installed.
*   Open your Start Menu and search for "Git Bash".
*   This is a special terminal where `git` is guaranteed to work. You can type commands there just like in PowerShell.

**3. Use a Windows Package Manager (Automated)**
If you use Chocolatey or Winget, you can force a reinstall that sets the path correctly:
*   **Winget:** `winget install --id Git.Git -e --source winget`
*   **Chocolatey:** `choco install git`

# <a id="src-main"></a> FY2025 Strategic Outlook and Financial Performance Targets

Based on the Q1 FY2025 earnings call transcript, management provided the following specific guidance and targets.

### **1\. Full Year FY2025 Targets**

Management reiterated some prior guidance while raising targets for Adjusted EBITDA and Free Cash Flow.

*   **Total Revenue:** "Our FY '25 outlook for total revenue remains unchanged at **$2.4 billion to $2.5 billion**"[[Source 1]](#src-1).
*   **Total Gross Margin:** The outlook "remains unchanged at **49%**"[[Source 1]](#src-1).
*   **Adjusted EBITDA:** Management raised the guidance range by 40million.LizCoddingtonstated : "WeareraisingourFY^{â€²}25adjustedEBITDAguidance...to âˆ— âˆ—240 million to $290 million\*\*"[[Source 1]](#src-1).
*   **Free Cash Flow:** "We are also raising our free cash flow target to **at least $125 million** an increase of $50 million from our previous guidance"[[Source 2]](#src-2).
*   **Paid Connected Fitness Subscriptions:** The guidance range of "**2.68 million to 2.75 million** remains unchanged"[[Source 3]](#src-3).
*   **Paid App Subscriptions:** Management lowered this guidance by 20,000 subscriptions to a range of "**550,000 to 600,000**"[[Source 4]](#src-4).
*   **Churn:** Management expects "average net monthly paid connected fitness churn will continue to **increase modestly year over year**"[[Source 3]](#src-3).

### **2\. Q2 FY2025 Expectations**

For the second quarter, management provided specific ranges reflecting seasonal trends and increased marketing spend.

*   **Total Revenue:** "**$640 million to $660 million**," which reflects a sequential increase due to holiday hardware sales[[Source 5]](#src-5).
*   **Paid Connected Fitness Subscriptions:** "**2.84 million to 2.86 million**," reflecting a "sequential decrease of 50,000 subscribers at the midpoint"[[Source 6]](#src-6).
*   **Paid App Subscriptions:** "**560,000 to 580,000**," reflecting a sequential decrease of 12,000 subscribers[[Source 5]](#src-5).
*   **Total Gross Margin:** "**46.5%**," which reflects an expected sequential decline "as a result of a seasonal mix shift toward our connected fitness Product segment"[[Source 5]](#src-5).
*   **Adjusted EBITDA:** "**$20 million to $30 million**," reflecting a sequential decline mainly due to "higher sales and marketing expenses as we increased media spend for the holiday season"[[Source 3]](#src-3).
*   **Churn:** Management expects the churn rate to "**slightly improve sequentially** in Q2"[[Source 6]](#src-6).

### **3\. Cost Restructuring Milestones**

Management confirmed they are on track to meet the savings goals announced in the May 2024 restructuring plan.

*   **Total Run-Rate Savings:** Interim Co-CEO Karen Boone reiterated the goal of "delivering **over $200 million of run rate cost savings** by the end of fiscal year '25"[[Source 7]](#src-7).
*   **Payroll-Related Savings (Completed):** CFO Liz Coddington confirmed that as of the end of Q1, they have "actioned all payroll-related changes that were assumed in the restructuring plan, which will deliver **over $100 million of annualized run rate savings**"[[Source 8]](#src-8).
*   **Additional Efficiencies:** Management noted they are realizing some savings "faster than we anticipated" and finding "additional cost efficiency through **reductions to media spend** that were not included in our $200 million restructuring goals"[[Source 8]](#src-8).

# <a id="src-1"></a>Source: q1 2025 earnings call transcript.md (Citation 1)



## [Main Content](#src-main) 

Any changes in these areas may affect our gross additions for paid connected fitness subscription across the fiscal year. Our full year guidance range for paid app subscriptions of 550,000 to 600,000, a 20,000 reduction versus our prior guidance reflects our decision to limit app media spend as we invest in product development to improve the member experience. Additionally, as we continue to improve our member experience, we see clear opportunities to improve engagement, which could result in favorability to churn for both connected fitness and app. While we are optimistic we can improve engagement through product and content innovation and evolving our marketing strategy, the timing of when we will start to see meaningful impact from these efforts is uncertain and, therefore, not reflected in our guidance.

Our primary focus for FY '25 is delivering our key financial results, which include total revenue, total gross margin, and adjusted EBITDA. We are prioritizing these metrics, along with delivering free cash flow. Our FY '25 outlook for total revenue remains unchanged at $2.4 billion to $2.5 billion, as well as our outlook for total gross margin, which remains unchanged at 49%. We are raising our FY '25 adjusted EBITDA guidance by $40 million to $240 million to $290 million, which reflects our continued improvement in profitability, largely due to gross margin expansion the operating cost savings we expect to achieve related to our previously announced cost restructuring plan and reduced media spend year over year.

# <a id="src-2"></a>Source: q1 2025 earnings call transcript.md (Citation 2)



## [Main Content](#src-main) 

Our primary focus for FY '25 is delivering our key financial results, which include total revenue, total gross margin, and adjusted EBITDA. We are prioritizing these metrics, along with delivering free cash flow. Our FY '25 outlook for total revenue remains unchanged at $2.4 billion to $2.5 billion, as well as our outlook for total gross margin, which remains unchanged at 49%. We are raising our FY '25 adjusted EBITDA guidance by $40 million to $240 million to $290 million, which reflects our continued improvement in profitability, largely due to gross margin expansion the operating cost savings we expect to achieve related to our previously announced cost restructuring plan and reduced media spend year over year.

We are also raising our free cash flow target to at least $125 million an increase of $50 million from our previous guidance, primarily from lower inventory production that we expect to create a greater working capital tailwind, as well as continued operating expense efficiencies. Following our Q1 free cash flow result of $11 million, we do expect to achieve positive free cash flow in all four quarters of the fiscal year. We expect to make meaningful progress in deleveraging our balance sheet throughout FY '25 and beyond. And now I'd like to turn it back to Chris for some closing remarks.

# <a id="src-3"></a>Source: q1 2025 earnings call transcript.md (Citation 3)



## [Main Content](#src-main) 

Our Q2 FY '25 ending paid app subscription outlook of 560,000 to 580,000 reflects a sequential decrease of 12,000 subscribers at the midpoint, as a result of a decision to limit app media spend. # <a id="src-1"></a>Source: q1 2026 earnings call transcript.md (Citation 1)



## [Main Content](#src-main) 

We ended the quarter with 542,000 ending paid app subscriptions, inclusive of subscriptions from our acquisition of Breathwrk. Total revenue was $551 million in Q1, comprising $152 million of Connected Fitness products revenue and $398 million of subscription revenue, outperforming the high end of our guidance range by $6 million. Outperformance relative to guidance was primarily driven by Connected Fitness products revenue from higher-than-expected hardware sales of both Peloton and Precor products. Connected Fitness products revenue decreased $7 million or 5% year-over-year, driven by lower equipment sales and deliveries, partially offset by a mix toward higher-priced products.

# <a id="src-2"></a>Source: q1 2026 earnings call transcript.md (Citation 2)



## [Main Content](#src-main) 

Liz Coddington Chief Financial Officer

Thanks, Peter. I want to begin with our first quarter financial results in which we exceeded the high end of our guidance on most key metrics. We ended the first quarter with 2.732 million Paid Connected Fitness Subscriptions, reflecting a decrease of 6% year-over-year. Q1 is typically a seasonally lower quarter for hardware sales and seasonally higher quarter for churn. We exceeded the high end of our guidance range by 2,000, driven by higher-than-expected gross additions. Connected Fitness gross additions outperformed our expectations due to higher unit sales of our Connected Fitness products in both first-party and third-party retail channels. Average net monthly Paid Connected Fitness Subscription churn was 1.6%, an improvement of 20 basis points both year-over-year and 10 basis points quarter-over-quarter, in line with our expectations.

# <a id="src-3"></a>Source: q1 2026 earnings call transcript.md (Citation 3)



## [Main Content](#src-main) 

Adjusted EBITDA was $118 million in Q1, which was a $2 million or 2% improvement year-over-year and $18 million above the high end of our guidance range. To note, the $13.5 million accrual for Bike+ seat post inventory costs was not added back to adjusted EBITDA. We generated $67 million of free cash flow in Q1, an increase of $57 million year-over-year, significantly outperforming our prior expectation for slightly negative cash flow in the quarter. Free cash flow benefited from tariff-related favorability associated with both lower-than-expected tariff rates and delayed timing for certain tariffs going into effect, lower operating costs associated with realizing indirect cost savings faster than anticipated, revenue favorability and other smaller impacts.

# <a id="src-4"></a>Source: q1 2026 earnings call transcript.md (Citation 4)



## [Main Content](#src-main) 

Subscription revenue decreased $28 million or 7% year-over-year, primarily driven by lower ending Paid Connected Fitness Subscriptions, lower content licensing revenue and lower ending paid app subscriptions, partly offset by used equipment activation fee revenue, which was introduced in late August of fiscal 2025. Total gross profit was $284 million in Q1, a decrease of $20 million or 7% year-over-year. Total gross margin was 51.5%, a decrease of 30 basis points year-over-year and 50 basis points below our guidance of 52%. Total gross margin was negatively impacted by a $13.5 million accrual for Bike+ seat post inventory costs this quarter, in addition to $3 million we accrued in the prior quarter, representing a total estimated impact of $16.5 million. Excluding this $13.5 million charge in Q1, total gross margin would have been 54% or 200 basis points above our Q1 guidance.

# <a id="src-5"></a>Source: q1 2026 earnings call transcript.md (Citation 5)



## [Main Content](#src-main) 

Next, I'd like to share context for our financial outlook for Q2 and the remainder of the fiscal year. Our full year fiscal 2026 revenue outlook of $2.4 billion to $2.5 billion is unchanged from what we provided last quarter and reflects a 2% revenue decrease year-over-year at the midpoint. Our recently announced changes to subscription pricing were incorporated into our previous full year outlook. And so far, the impact of those changes has been in line with our expectations. We are pleased that our members continue to see the value in their Peloton membership and the recently added benefits like Peloton IQ, Club Peloton, Breathwrk and more.

# <a id="src-6"></a>Source: q1 2026 earnings call transcript.md (Citation 6)



## [Main Content](#src-main) 

As we noted last quarter, our full year guidance anticipates an inflection toward growth during certain quarters within the fiscal year. Our Q2 revenue outlook of $665 million to $685 million reflects this expectation with a slight increase of 0.2% year-over-year at the midpoint and an increase of 23% quarter-over-quarter as a result of seasonally higher equipment sales and recent pricing changes. We are raising our full year fiscal 2026 guidance for total gross margin to 52%, which is an increase of 100 basis points from our prior guidance and an improvement of 110 basis points year-over-year, primarily driven by favorable tariff rates relative to our prior full year guidance as policy continues to evolve, a favorable mix of sales toward higher-margin products and our continued focus on driving cost efficiency to our supply chain. These tailwinds are partially offset by the accrual for the Bike+ seat post inventory impact in Q1.

# <a id="src-7"></a>Source: q1 2026 earnings call transcript.md (Citation 7)



## [Main Content](#src-main) 

Q2 total gross margin is expected to be roughly 49%, down 250 basis points quarter-over-quarter due to an expected seasonally higher mix of Connected Fitness products revenue. We are raising our full year fiscal 2026 guidance for adjusted EBITDA to $425 million to $475 million, reflecting an increase of $25 million from our prior guidance and an improvement of 12% year-over-year at the midpoint, driven by favorable gross profit and operating expenses, reflecting our expectation for realizing cost savings faster than previously anticipated. To note, we are increasing our full year guidance by $25 million, notwithstanding the $13.5 million accrual for Bike+ seat post inventory costs in Q1.

# <a id="src-8"></a>Source: q1 2026 earnings call transcript.md (Citation 8)



## [Main Content](#src-main) 

Generating meaningful free cash flow remains a top priority. We are raising our full year fiscal 2026 minimum free cash flow target by $50 million to at least $250 million, reflecting the benefit of lower tariffs, both from lower rates and later-than-expected implementation timing and our progress on realizing indirect cost savings sooner. This target reflects our expectations for a roughly $45 million impact to free cash flow as a result of tariff exposure, which remains a dynamic situation that may change in the future. Overall, our guidance for Q2 and the remainder of the fiscal year reflects continued improvement in profitability and progress toward revenue growth. We still expect to achieve the important milestone of positive operating income on a full year basis in fiscal 2026.

# <a id="src-9"></a>Source: q1 2026 earnings call transcript.md (Citation 9)



## [Main Content](#src-main) 

Our Q2 outlook for adjusted EBITDA of $55 million to $75 million reflects an increase of 11% year-over-year at the midpoint, but a decrease of 45% quarter-over-quarter due to seasonally higher marketing spend in Q2. Our Q2 guidance for ending Paid Connected Fitness Subscriptions of 2.64 million to 2.67 million reflects a decrease of 8% year-over-year at the midpoint. Average net monthly Paid Connected Fitness Subscription churn is expected to increase year-over-year and quarter-over-quarter due to an increase in subscription cancellations and pauses following our pricing changes announced on October 1. However, our guidance reflects an expectation that our net churn rate will be flat year-over-year in full year fiscal 2026. We also expect gross additions to decrease year-over-year as a result of an expected year-over-year decrease in hardware sales.

### 2\. Instances where Management **Lowered** Guidance

Management lowered guidance in only one specific instance within the provided transcripts, related to App subscriptions.

*   **Q1 FY2025 Call (Oct 31, 2024):**
    *   **Metric:** FY2025 Paid App Subscriptions.
    *   **Decrease:** Lowered by **20,000 subscriptions** (New range: 550kâ€“600k).
    *   **Reason:** Management made a strategic decision to limit media spend for the App while investing in product development to improve the member experience before spending to acquire new users[[Source 11]](#src-11).

### 3\. Instances where Management **Declined** or **Withdrew** Guidance

Management explicitly declined to provide specific guidance on certain metrics, citing uncertainty or internal policy.

*   **Future Engagement Benefits (Q1 FY2025 & Q2 FY2025):**
    *   **Declined to Guide:** Management declined to incorporate potential upside from software innovation (such as "Teams" or personalized plans) into their financial guidance.
    *   **Reason:** The timing and magnitude of when these innovations would meaningfully impact engagement and retention were deemed "uncertain"[[Source 11]](#src-11)[[Source 12]](#src-12).
*   **Specific Churn Guidance (Q2 FY2025):**
    *   **Declined to Guide:** When asked for specific churn numbers for the remainder of the year, CFO Liz Coddington stated, "We don't guide specifically to churn," though she provided directional expectations that churn would remain relatively in line with Q2 levels[[Source 13]](#src-13).
*   **Subscription Pricing Plans (Q2 FY2025):**
    *   **Declined to Guide:** When asked how investors should think about potential price increases, CEO Peter Stern declined to provide specifics, stating, "We won't take any actions there lightly. So beyond what I've shared so far, that's about all we have to say today"[[Source 14]](#src-14)[[Source 15]](#src-15).

On August 12, 2022, as part of our previously announced ongoing restructuring initiatives, we announced the decision to rebalance our e-commerce and retail mix to drive efficiencies and therefore reduce our retail showroom presence across North America.

_Membership & Member Support Services_ The Membership team, which includes third-party support providers, is focused on driving engagement to help us maintain our high Connected Fitness Subscription retention rates. The team develops new ways to promote engagement with our products and community or help Members reengage with our platform when activity has lapsed. The Membership team helps curate goal-based challenges, awards digital badges for Member accomplishments, and sends Peloton-branded â€œCentury Clubâ€ shirts after a Memberâ€™s 100 class. The team also communicates with Members with no recent activity through email campaigns that help encourage these Members to get back to their workout routine. In addition, the Membership team collects and responds to feedback about our platform that is on our primary Facebook group of over 469,000 Members as of June 30, 2022.

# <a id="src-main"></a> Peloton: Strategic Pivot and the Path to Growth

Based on the J.P. Morgan analyst reports from August and November 2025, the firm maintains a **Neutral** rating on Peloton. The analysts acknowledge Peloton's status as a market leader with a loyal base but highlight significant challenges regarding the company's ability to return to sustainable top-line growth.

### **Competitive Positioning**

J.P. Morgan positions Peloton as the dominant player in interactive fitness, characterized by a unique vertically integrated business model.

*   **Market Leadership and Scale:** Peloton is identified as the "largest interactive fitness platform in the world" with over 6 million members globally[[Source 1]](#src-1)[[Source 2]](#src-2). The analysts note that Peloton's membership represents only ~4% of global gym memberships, suggesting a significant theoretical runway for future growth[[Source 1]](#src-1)[[Source 2]](#src-2).
*   **Vertically Integrated Model:** A key competitive advantage identified is Peloton's control over the "entire member journey" through its vertically integrated model (hardware, software, and content). This allows the company to deliver a "members-first mission" and drives a "passionate and highly engaged member base"[[Source 3]](#src-3)[[Source 4]](#src-4).
*   **Valuation Discount:** Despite its market leadership, Peloton trades at a discount compared to consumer subscription peers. As of November 2025, the price target of $9.00 is based on ~12x CY27 estimated Free Cash Flow (FCF), representing a discount to peers trading at an average of ~38x due to Peloton's "lower growth & profit profile"[[Source 5]](#src-5).

### **Key Opportunities**

The reports highlight several strategic initiatives implemented by CEO Peter Stern intended to drive profitability and eventually restore growth.

*   **Strategic Pivot to Wellness:** A major opportunity identified is broadening Pelotonâ€™s focus beyond cardio fitness to include "wellness." This includes scaling offerings in **Strength** and entering new categories such as **Meditation, Sleep, Recovery, Nutrition, and Hydration**[[Source 6]](#src-6)[[Source 7]](#src-7).
*   **Cost Rationalization and Efficiency:** J.P. Morgan views the company's cost discipline positively. Peloton is on track to realize over **$100 million in annualized savings** by the end of FY2026 through headcount reductions, lower indirect spend, and work relocation[[Source 8]](#src-8)[[Source 9]](#src-9). The analysts are encouraged by the company's progress in improving profit, ramping FCF, and deleveraging the balance sheet[[Source 6]](#src-6)[[Source 10]](#src-10).
*   **Product Innovation:** The analysts point to investments in driving awareness for new products, specifically the **Peloton Cross Training Series** and **Peloton IQ** (AI-driven personalization), as key drivers for future growth[[Source 8]](#src-8)[[Source 11]](#src-11).
*   **Pricing and Monetization:** There is an opportunity to improve unit economics through pricing adjustments. This includes rationalizing promotions, introducing optional expert assembly fees, and potential upside from All-Access subscription price increases[[Source 7]](#src-7)\> <[[Source 12]](#src-12)[[Source 13]](#src-13).
*   **Commercial and Retail Expansion:** The creation of a **unified commercial business unit** combining Peloton and Precor is seen as a strategic lever to expand reach[[Source 14]](#src-14). Additionally, the analysts note the plan to expand from one to ten "microstores" to grow physical presence efficiently[[Source 15]](#src-15).

### **Key Threats and Risks**

Despite the operational improvements, J.P. Morgan identifies substantial risks, primarily centered on the uncertainty of demand and intense market competition.

*   **Visibility on Growth:** The most significant threat identified is the difficulty in returning to Connected Fitness (CF) subscriber and revenue growth. The analysts note that "visibility is limited given secular & macro pressures" and that a return to growth remains "challenging"[[Source 3]](#src-3)[[Source 4]](#src-4).
*   **Intense Competition:** The reports identify heavy competition as a downside risk, specifically citing **Apple Fitness+, Equinox/SoulCycle, BODY, Tonal, and Tempo** as key rivals[[Source 16]](#src-16)[[Source 17]](#src-17).
*   **Macroeconomic and Tariff Headwinds:** The company faces "secular & macro pressures"[[Source 3]](#src-3). Specific headwinds include tariffs, with Peloton anticipating additional reciprocal tariffs on imported tablets from Thailand and existing tariffs on aluminum content[[Source 8]](#src-8)[[Source 15]](#src-15).
*   **Valuation Support:** There is a risk regarding "less traditional valuation support" compared to subscription peers, as there is no clear comparable company and limited visibility into near-term demand trends[[Source 18]](#src-18)[[Source 19]](#src-19).

Based on the **ESG Reports (including the 2025 Impact Report)** and **Proxy Statements** from FY2023 to FY2025, here is the breakdown of Peloton's workforce changes and restructuring efforts.

### **Current Employee Count**

As of **June 30, 2025**, Pelotonâ€™s global workforce consisted of **2,656 team members**[[Source 1]](#src-1).

*   **Note on Composition:** This figure includes employees of Precor, a wholly-owned subsidiary[[Source 2]](#src-2).

### **Workforce Reductions and Trends (FY2023â€“FY2025)**

The documentation reveals a consistent downward trend in headcount as the company executed multiple restructuring plans to right-size its operations.

**Key Observation:** The decline in core Peloton staff is significant. While the FY2023 count (3,584) excluded Precor, the FY2025 count (2,656) _includes_ Precor, indicating that the reduction in legacy Peloton staff is steeper than the headline numbers suggest.

### **Specific Restructuring Actions**

The Proxy Statements and ESG reports highlight three major restructuring phases aimed at reducing fixed costs and improving cash flow.

*   **2022 Restructuring Plan:** Initiated to realign operational focus, this plan involved "getting the right people in the right roles" and stabilizing cash flow[[Source 5]](#src-5). The ESG report noted that the company provided support to team members impacted by this restructuring, including cash compensation, extended healthcare, and career support services[[Source 6]](#src-6).
*   **2024 Restructuring Plan:** Announced in May 2024, this plan aimed to position the company for sustained positive free cash flow. It included a **global headcount reduction of approximately 15%**, which impacted roughly **400 team members**[[Source 7]](#src-7)[[Source 8]](#src-8).
*   **2025 Restructuring Plan:** In August 2025, the company announced a new plan involving further "reduction in global headcount" to achieve at least **$100 million in run-rate cost savings** by the end of Fiscal 2026[[Source 9]](#src-9)[[Source 10]](#src-10).

### **Workforce Strategy & Support**

Despite the reductions, the ESG and Proxy reports emphasize a strategy of "talent density" and support for the remaining workforce:

*   **Compensation:** The company completed pay equity studies in FY2023 and FY2025, finding no statistically significant pay gaps based on gender or race[[Source 11]](#src-11)[[Source 12]](#src-12).
*   **Wages:** Peloton offers a starting hourly rate of no less than $19 for non-sales hourly roles in the US[[Source 12]](#src-12).
*   **Engagement:** In FY2025, the company reported an engagement score of 77% favorable and an Employee Net Promoter Score (eNPS) of 74%, an increase of 12 points from the prior year[[Source 13]](#src-13).
